text: hi hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review yeah Buchan case
general dome you can gaze is a musical
duo from New York I believe this is
their second full-length LP and I will
most sure for certainly definitely yeah
be the first to admit that for quite a
while I mean I guess since their debut
LP I've always kind of dismissed this
project not publicly but you know sort
of personally thinking that maybe they
were a little too enthralled with their
homemade instruments to the point where
they would name their musical project
after them that sort of thing just kind
of screams the word gimmick to me and
despite the fact that they may have been
able to conjure some semi unique sounds
with the instruments that they made you
know ultimately the question comes up is
there as much attention being paid
toward the music and the songwriting
that was my perception that was sort of
my attitude toward their first album but
I gave this new LP of there's an
honest-to-god shot and was pleasantly
surprised because I think what I ended
up finding on this LP was a lot of
improvement and just a lot of appeal for
one the production the sound the overall
sound recording on this LP is is loads
better no longer does buchen case sound
I guess as tattered and sort of worn as
their homemade setup is kind of strung
together with maybe a little bit of tape
some screws and some daisy-chained
effects pedals and what's kind of come
through in the process of maybe me
giving them a better try and just
hearing a better recording is that these
guys have essentially kind of revealed
themselves as being a pretty unique and
interesting noise pop project they just
have this really strong sense of
eccentricity a penchant for kind of very
strange angular melodies a lot like
Deerhoof maybe not in the same exact way
but the way that they write melodies the
way they just come out so sharp there
are also moments where just the tone and
the dissonance and just the strain
the chaos kind of reminds me of like
Mika Chu in the shapes without the
British swagger or sort of post-punk
influence and there are other moments on
here where I'm sort of feeling a really
strong Dirty Projectors kind of vibe
coming especially from the guitar riffs
and and lines and melodies there isn't
really kind of that virtuous flash from
the playing that you would usually get
on a Dirty Projectors record but the
melodies and just the writing on on this
album are no less dizzying and and
maze-like buchen cases kind of
idiosyncratic approach toward writing
melodies and and structuring songs with
kind of one phase after another but yet
it all kind of comes together in verses
and choruses is so damn impenetrable and
yet it's so kind of odd and and just
sharp sounding overall that I can't help
but pay attention to it it is attention
demanding beside for maybe like the soft
interlude in the middle of contortion
and training very little about this LP
actually comes off as being smooth one
track after another you're getting all
these staccato guitar riffs and and
leads that sort of hammer away
mechanically right underneath Aaron
dyers I'll use this word again very
sharp sharp feminine voice it's got a
nice twang to it I guess not a southern
twang but it's like you know got a
really kind of it just kind of hangs in
this certain pitch range that again a
lot like the guitars is just kind of
sitting in this register where you can't
help but pay attention to it it is like
onion freakin normal enig normal which
may be annoying to some people
especially if they're kind of maybe
looking for music that will help them
chill out relax this is very much not in
that mood to me this new buchen gas LP
instead is is more like an imaginative
crossroad between sort of like the
hard-hitting and just straight rigid
sounds of industrial combined with just
stomping hollering hootenanny party
attitude especially on the track pickup
which has all these kind of thumping
drums on it
a lot of dissonant background guitar
plays some Basie and patient guitarrists
which are just kind of laying a nice
solid rhythmic foundation des have a
very kind of grinding just sandpaper
rough quality to them you can gaze
definitely conjure up a very dense array
of sounds for just two people with you
know some homemade instruments the title
track on this thing is just guitar
noises upon guitar noises with ass down
on the riff and over that are all these
weird leads and just kind of freak outs
and when they kind of kick in with these
thick scrum cords that are just so
freakin dissonant on top of this it's
like this downward spiral into just sour
tones there are these swaths of just
chromatically ascending guitar leaves on
the track
twisting the lasso of truth which
totally earns its freakin title and it
just feels like this insanely maniacal
take on like circus music however my one
issue with the track is that it doesn't
really develop past the climax of this
one really good musical idea that it
presents and there are a few other
tracks on here like the closing track
two that do kind of feel like that like
buchen gates are more interested in kind
of doing this weird experiment than they
are actually kind of crafting song but
most of the time on this album in their
own weird little way buchen gates are
bringing some catchy melodic weirdly
melodic verse chorus verse tracks that
kind of sound like an old airplane
engine on its last leg topped with
guitar leads they're just kind of burn
their way into my eardrums mainly on the
track hard times now there is a nice
sense of variety among these tracks they
don't really get that kind of album arc
or just sort of an obvious progression
or anything like that especially with
two strangely placed interlude tracks
but like I said there are differences
and I guess sort of feel among these
songs there are slower tracks faster
tracks denser tracks more sparse tracks
louder softer but nothing on here purely
comes off is sweet straightforward or
basic which is you know also praise but
I guess kind of warning as well for
those who may be looking for
that kind of thing because as fun as
this album is to listen to for me I will
admit that to an extent it does sound
kind of say me say me with the errands
kind of relying on you know their same
instruments over and over
I mean rarely do they kind of break out
of the I guess sort of ritual of relying
on their buek and gates to make these
songs kind of work but you know I guess
you would figure considering in the name
of the group there are moments where
keyboards kind of come in maybe a few
gentler guitar tones there's even a spot
on here that really sticks out because
it's got auto-tune on it but you know
it's not really in the way you usually
kind of see auto-tune getting used these
guys take an eccentric approach toward
executing with that just like they do
the guitar and bass so even though this
album is a little bit of a gauntlet at a
kind of short 42 minutes I did love
listening to it it is just an odd gift
it's a fun puzzle it's catchy yet
challenging it's a friendly conundrum it
is a joyous racket I'm feeling a decent
too strong eight on this album if you've
given it a listen did you love it hate
it why and what do you think I should
review next anthony Fantana
Buchan case forever
